entry.title: In global employee well-being survey, India second after Turkiye; Japan last
entry.summary: Japan came in last in a global ranking of employees' well being, measured by assessing physical, mental, social and spiritual health, the results of a survey conducted by McKinsey health institute showed. The island nation scored 25% in the poll of more than 30,000 workers across 30 countries, according to the study. Turkiye was highest at 78%, followed by 76% for India and 75% for China. The global average was 57%. According to the survey, employees who had positive work experiences reported better holistic health, are more innovative at work and show higher job performance.

entry.title: FTX crypto mogul convicted of fraud, faces max of 110 yrs in jail
entry.summary: Sam Bankman-Fried, the founder of FTX cryptocurrency exchange, has been convicted of fraud by a New York jury. The jury found him guilty of stealing at least $10 billion from customers and investors. Bankman-Fried, once worth over $20 billion, is now facing a maximum sentence of 110 years. The conviction is a significant victory for US attorney Damian Williams, who described Bankman-Fried's actions as "one of the biggest financial frauds in US history." Bankman-Fried is expected to appeal the verdict.

entry.title: US drones fly over Gaza in search for American hostages
entry.summary: The US has been flying surveillance drones over Gaza in search of hostages taken by Hamas when the Palestinian militant group attacked Israel on Oct. 7, two US officials said. The officials said the US was flying intelligence gathering drones over Gaza to assist with hostage location efforts. One of the officials said they had been carrying out the drone flights for over a week. US officials said 10 Americans who remain unaccounted for may be among the more than 200 taken as hostages into Gaza, where they are believed to be held in Hamas' extensive tunnel network.

entry.title: Wagner to give Hezbollah air defence system? Kremlin dismisses report
entry.summary: The Kremlin on Friday dismissed a Wall Street Journal report that United States intelligence believed Russia's Wagner mercenary group plans to provide Hezbollah with an air defence system, saying such talk was unfounded. "We have already said that, de-facto, such a group (Wagner) does not exist," Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov said. "All of these musings are as a rule based on nothing and have no foundation," Peskov said when asked about the report.

entry.title: Mark Zuckerberg undergoes surgery for martial arts knee injury
entry.summary: Meta Platforms Inc. Chief Executive Officer Mark Zuckerberg underwent surgery to repair a torn knee ligament sustained during a mixed martial arts session, he said Friday in a post on Instagram. “Tore my ACL sparring and just got out of surgery to replace it,” Zuckerberg wrote in the caption of a post with a series of photos showing him in a hospital bed, his knee bandaged and in a brace. The CEO, 39, said he plans to continuing his training for “a competitive MMA fight early next year.”

entry.title: Maine mass shooter was alive for most of massive 2-day search, autopsy suggests
entry.summary: The Army reservist who carried out the shootings in a bowling alley and a bar in Lewiston, Maine, was alive and potentially on the run for more than 24 hours after the incident, according to the state's medical examiner. Robert Card died from a self-inflicted gunshot, which likely occurred eight to 12 hours before his body was found in a tractor-trailer. Concerns about Card's mental state had been raised prior to the shootings, and law enforcement agencies came under scrutiny for not finding his body sooner.

entry.title: North Korean art sells in China despite UN sanctions over nuclear programme
entry.summary: A Chinese art gallery, The Paintings Say Arirang, is openly selling North Korean art in Beijing, despite UN sanctions prohibiting such sales. The gallery, which operates a studio for North Korean artists, showcases the unique socialist realist style of North Korean art that appeals to a niche audience. China's lax enforcement of the sanctions targeting North Korea's nuclear program allows for the continued sale of North Korean art. The art is seen as a form of propaganda, with artists working directly for North Korea's authorities to create art glorifying the state and its ideology.

entry.title: Solar storm causes pumpkin-colored auroras to fill sky
entry.summary: A recent solar storm caused a unique combination of red and green lights in the night sky above Canada, creating a strange image of orange pillars. Experts say that orange auroras shouldn't exist as the color is usually overwhelmed by other colors given off by excited molecules. The phenomenon was captured in a photograph by aurora photographer Harlan Thomas, who described the orange hue as "sublime." The last time such vibrant orange auroras were seen was during the Halloween storm of 2003.

entry.title: The Gaza-Egypt Rafah crossing explained: ‘It is not a normal border’
entry.summary: For Gaza's two million residents, the Rafah border with Egypt serves as a vital lifeline. Over the years, this crossing has seen numerous shifts, openings, and closures, prompting the construction of illicit tunnels beneath it to facilitate the flow of people and goods. As the war between Israel and Hamas persists, the Rafah border now plays a crucial role in evacuations and the delivery of humanitarian aid.

entry.title: Argentina: Unpalatable Choices in Election Plagued with Uncertainty
entry.summary:
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Nov 03 (IPS) - For many of Argentina’s voters the choice in the 19 November presidential runoff is between the lesser of two evils: Sergio Massa, economy minister of a government that’s presiding over a once-in-a-generation economic meltdown with a whopping 140-per cent inflation rate, or Javier Milei, a far-right libertarian who admires Donald Trump, wants to shut down the Central Bank and wields a chainsaw in public as a symbol of his willingness to slash the state. Many will rue that it ever came to this.

Read the full story, “Argentina: Unpalatable Choices in Election Plagued with Uncertainty”, on globalissues.org →

entry.title: Israeli President meets with envoys whose citizens were murdered and abducted by Hamas
entry.summary: Israeli President Isaac Herzog met with the ambassadors of Thailand, the Philippines, Tanzania, and Nepal to discuss the terror invasion carried out by Hamas in southwestern Israel. The ambassadors expressed concern for their citizens who were killed, injured, or taken hostage during the attack. President Herzog emphasized that Hamas does not differentiate between religions or countries and assured the ambassadors that the Israeli people appreciate their citizens. Among foreign countries, Thailand had the second-highest number of fatalities and a significant number of citizens taken hostage by Hamas. The Thai ambassador expressed concern for the well-being of the Thai people in Israel and asked for assistance in locating and helping the abducted individuals.

entry.title: Storm Ciaran kills 5, taking European death toll to 12
entry.summary: Record-breaking rain produced floods in a vast swath of Italy's Tuscany region as Storm Ciaran pushed into the country overnight trapping residents in their homes, inundating hospitals and overturning cars. At least five people were killed, bringing the storm's death toll in western Europe to 12 on Friday. Italian Civil Protection authorities said 200 millimeters (nearly 8 inches) of rain fell in a three-hour period, from the coastal city of Livorno to the inland valley of Mugello, and caused riverbanks to overflow. Video shows at least a dozen cars getting pushed down a flooded road.

entry.title: Bollywood superstars: Paris exhibition delves into a century of Indian cinema
entry.summary: In this special edition of Access Asia, we're at Paris's Quai Branly museum, where a new exhibition, "Bollywood superstars", looks back at a century of the Indian film industry. With more than 2,000 movies per year, Bollywood is the biggest movie industry in the world. It evolved from performing arts and silent films to today's big blockbusters. We speak to the exhibition's co-curator Julien Rousseau, as well as Mahina Khanum, a Bollywood dancer and choreographer. Plus, we explore how India's ruling Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) is increasingly using the country's cinema to push its Hindu nationalist agenda.

entry.title: Iran sentences a woman to death for adultery
entry.summary: An Iranian court has sentenced a female gym trainer to death for adultery. The woman's husband reported her to the police after finding her with another man at their home, whom he discovered through surveillance cameras. Although Iranian law allows for appeals, the country has faced international criticism for its frequent use of the death penalty. The United Nations Secretary-General, Antonio Guterres, warned that Iran was executing people at an "alarming rate." Crimes such as adultery, sodomy, murder, rape, armed robbery, kidnapping, and drug trafficking are all punishable by death in Iran.

entry.title: China jet fired flares at Canadian chopper in international waters: Ottawa
entry.summary: Canadian defence minister Bill Blair informed the press on Friday that a Chinese military aircraft discharged flares toward a Canadian helicopter in international waters the previous Sunday. He stated that Ottawa intends to communicate its concerns to Beijing. This marks the second instance within a two-week period where Canada has raised accusations of unsafe conduct by China's air force. In mid-October, Minister Blair reported that a Chinese fighter jet had approached within five meters (approximately 16 feet) of a surveillance aircraft engaged in a United Nations mission.

entry.title: Morocco unearths Roman-era second century site in Rabat
entry.summary: Archaeologists in Morocco have discovered a Roman-era site in Rabat, which includes a port district, bath, and cemetery dating back to the second century. The site, now the third largest in Morocco, will provide insights into the lives of Roman settlers and romanised Moroccans during that time. The bath covers an area of over 2000 square meters and resembles imperial counterparts in Rome. The excavation is ongoing to uncover the port and other parts of one of the largest Roman towns in the country.

entry.title: Syria's Raqqa struggles to rebuild after years of rule by Islamic State group
entry.summary: The city of Raqqa symbolises the tragic fate of Syria over the past 12 years. From the start of the uprising against President Bashar al-Assad in 2011, the northern city was a major target for rebel groups. It then became the stronghold of Islamic State group terrorists, who made Raqqa the capital of their self-proclaimed caliphate. The city went through three years of hell – suffering atrocities, public hangings and slave auctions – before being bombed and then liberated in 2017 by an international US-led coalition. Since then, the "Pearl of the Euphrates" has struggled to get back on track.

entry.title: Inflection Point: How to Reverse the Erosion of U.S. and Allied Military Power and Influence
entry.summary: As diplomatic efforts in Europe and Asia intensify, so too should U.S. military planning and preparations for a world that is drastically different and more dangerous than it was just a decade ago. For the past decade and a half, wargaming and analysis have pointed to the conclusion that the U.S. defense strategy and posture have become insolvent. The tasks that the U.S. government and its citizens expect their military forces and other elements of national power to do internationally greatly exceed the means available to accomplish those tasks. We address this problem in our new report, Inflection Point: How The post Inflection Point: How to Reverse the Erosion of U.S. and Allied Military Power and Influence appeared first on War on the Rocks.

Oct. 27 – Nov. 2, 2023

Oct. 27-Nov. 2, 2023
A student activist resists detention while gathering to protest against Israel’s military operations in Gaza and to support the Palestinian people, in New Delhi. Activists of the Bangladesh Nationalist Party face police during a protest in Dhaka. A devotee lights oil lamps during celebrations of the full moon day of Thadingyut, or lighting festival, to mark the end of Buddhist Lent in Naypyitaw, Myanmar.
This photo gallery highlights some of the most compelling images in Asia made or published by The Associated Press in the past week.
The selection was curated by AP photo editor Masayo Yoshida in Tokyo.

entry.title: Nazanin Boniadi takes aim at UN for letting Iran ‘legitimise itself’
entry.summary:
British-Iranian actress Nazanin Boniadi has taken aim at the United Nations for enabling the Islamic Republic of Iran to use the organisation to “legitimise itself”.
Ms Boniadi sat down with Sky News Australia host Laura Jayes to discuss the dangerous regime of the Islamic Republic of Iran.
Ms Boniadi urged the West to enforce sanctions on Iranian officials amid the rampant human rights abuses in the country.
She said the Islamic Republic is using the United Nations to “normalise” itself to the global public.
“The problem with the UN is … when UN member states and their representatives don’t stand for democracy, and they play into the Islamic Republic’s propaganda and side with them, then we’re never going to see change,” she told Sky News Australia.

entry.title: Volunteers cleaning California lake on Halloween find 'murdered' man in suitcase
entry.summary: A man's body was discovered inside a discarded suitcase during a routine cleanup around Oakland's Lake Merritt on Halloween. Volunteers found the body when they realized the suitcase was too heavy and unzipped it. The victim, believed to be in his 30s, was found in a fetal position. The investigation is ongoing, and authorities are trying to determine where the body could have come from. The incident has caused shock among local residents who consider the area a peaceful spot.

entry.title: 'In Senegal, homophobia follows you even after death': Mob exhumes, burns corpse
entry.summary: A mob in a small town in Senegal dug up the body of a man suspected of being gay, dragged his body through the streets and then burned it during the night of October 28, 2023. While there have been other instances of exhumations of people suspected of being gay, the incident that took place in Kaolack, a town 200 kilometres southeast of Dakar, is different because it was filmed and posted online, says our Observer, a member of a group dedicated to upholding the human rights of LGBT Africans.

American Airlines has since terminated its contract with the company and switched to a new uniform supplier.

Timothoes Powell, 29, was taken into custody on Monday and is facing a first-degree aggravated child abuse charge. The incident came to light when a state Department of Children and Families investigator noticed the child's injuries. Powell initially claimed that he found a piece of glass in the child's diaper, but later admitted to causing the injury.

Today, the vast area stretching from Mauritania to Sudan has become a no man's land for journalists, a black hole for news.

entry.title: Kashmir's Apple Industry Faces Dire Threats as Climate Change Takes its Toll
entry.summary:
SHOPIAN, INDIA, Nov 02 (IPS) - Of Kashmir’s seven million inhabitants, a staggering one million rely directly on apple farming. The region is pivotal in India’s apple and horticulture production, contributing to over 70 percent of the country’s apple supply. This not only provides income to farmers but also sustains a vast network of laborers, traders, and transporters within the fruit economy.

However, the American labor market continues to show resilience, with the economy adding jobs and consumer spending remaining strong.

entry.title: Putin signs bill revoking Russia's ratification of global nuke test ban treaty
entry.summary: President Vladimir Putin has signed a bill to revoke Russia's ratification of the Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty (CTBT), citing the need to establish parity with the United States. The CTBT, adopted in 1996, bans nuclear explosions globally but has not been fully implemented. Russia's move has raised concerns that it may resume nuclear tests to deter Western military support for Ukraine. However, Russian Deputy Foreign Minister Sergei Ryabkov stated that Moscow will only resume tests if the US does so first.

entry.summary: Thousands of people are flooding Pakistan's northwestern border crossing into Afghanistan after the government's deadline for undocumented foreigners to leave expired. Over a million Afghans may have to leave Pakistan or face arrest and forcible expulsion. More than 24,000 Afghans crossed into Afghanistan on Wednesday alone, with thousands more expected to follow.

The exact timeline and details of the evacuation were not provided. The Egyptian official clarified that 361 foreigners and dual nationals had entered Egypt on Wednesday. The number of wounded included 46 patients and 30 accompanying individuals.

entry.title: Magnitude 5.7 earthquake strikes central Philippines: USGS
entry.summary: An earthquake of magnitude 5.7 struck the central Philippines on Tuesday, the USGS said. The offshore quake was at a depth of 19.2 km (12 miles), USGS said, off the central province of Eastern Samar. The Philippine Institute of Volcanology and Seismology warned of damage and aftershocks in an advisory but there were no immediate reports of casualties. The Philippines lies on the "Ring of Fire", a belt of volcanoes circling the Pacific Ocean that is prone to earthquakes.

It was later revealed that the practitioner had no medical qualifications and the certificates he provided were fake.

entry.title: Extremists kill 37 villagers in latest attack in Nigeria's hard-hit northeast
entry.summary: Islamic extremist rebels in northeastern Nigeria killed at least 37 villagers in two separate attacks, marking a resurgence of violence in the region. The first attack occurred in Yobe state's Geidam district, where gunmen shot and killed 17 villagers. The following day, a land mine exploded, killing 20 people attending the burial of the victims from the previous attack. The Boko Haram group has been responsible for the insurgency in Nigeria since 2009, resulting in over 35,000 deaths and the displacement of millions of people.

entry.title: China agrees to nuclear arms-control talks with US: Report
entry.summary: China and the United States are set to hold their first nuclear arms control talks since the Obama administration. The discussions, scheduled for next week, will focus on arms control and non-proliferation, as well as maritime affairs and other issues. The talks come after US officials expressed frustration over China's lack of interest in reducing nuclear weapons risks. China currently has over 500 operational nuclear warheads, a number that is expected to rise to over 1,000 by 2030.

entry.title: 'Pathetic': Marjorie Taylor Greene attacks 'feckless Republicans' who voted against her
entry.summary:
She tried to censure and it came up short. Now she's shaming the names who didn't vote in favor. Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene (R-GA) had willed a resolution to censure Rep. Rashida Tlaib (D-MI) for her attendance of a protest opposing the war in Gaza. POLL: Should Trump be allowed to run for office? "List of feckless Republicans that voted WITH Democrats to table my censure resolution against Rashida Tlaib," Greene said on Wednesday. "This is why Republicans NEVER do anything to stop the communists Democrats or ever hold anyone accountable!! PATHETIC."
She created a social media thread naming some of her friends in the House who didn't have what it took to vote with her. They include current House Speaker Mike Johnson, Rep. Chip Roy (R-TX), and Rep. Ken Buck (R-CO) who announced he wasn't running for reelection.
Earlier in the week, Greene preemptively lashed out after learning that her effort wasn't gaining a coalition in Congress. "I want to remind you, this happened on the same day Hezbollah declared a day of immense anger," she said. "And Rashida Tlaib organized with that group. And they did. They did protest, and they did an insurrection into our Capitol complex, stopping Congress and stopping the Senate." The media was quick to take notice of the lawmaker's swing and miss Wednesday. "Colleague Kelly Phares rpts 23 GOPers join Dems to table or kill effort to censure Dem MI Rep Tlaib," tweeted Chat Pergram. Melanie Zanona also tweeted: "motion to table — aka kill — MTG’s resolution to censure Rep. Rashida Tlaib just passed the House, with help of 23 Republicans."
And CNN's Manu Raju added that the effort to take on Tlaib quickly died tweeting: "House kills resolution to censure Rashida Tlaib. 23 Republicans voted with Dems. MTG offered the resolution."

entry.title: Gaza's southern border crossing opens to evacuate some stranded foreign nationals
entry.summary: Gaza's southern border with Egypt was opened Wednesday for the first time since the Israel-Hamas war broke out on Oct. 7, to allow about 500 foreign nationals to evacuate Gaza and allow some critically-injured Palestinians to get medical treatment in Egypt. Diplomatic sources told CBS News that the evacuations were negotiated by the U.S. and Qatar. Charlie D'Agata has the latest.

entry.title: Pakistan: Six terrorists killed in Balochistan's Zhob
entry.summary: Six terrorists were killed during an operation in the Sambaza area of Balochistan's Zhob district. Security forces conducted the operation based on intelligence reports. The Inter-Services Public Relations (ISPR) stated that the terrorists were involved in activities against security forces and targeting innocent civilians. A cache of arms, ammunition, and explosives was also recovered. The area is being sanitized to eliminate other militants. Pakistan has witnessed an increase in terrorism, particularly in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa and Balochistan.

entry.title: Biden and the first lady will travel to Maine to mourn with the community after the mass shooting
entry.summary: President Joe Biden will visit the community of Lewiston, Maine, to mourn the victims of the deadliest mass shooting in the state's history. The shooting took place on October 25, resulting in 18 deaths and 13 injuries. Biden and First Lady Jill Biden will pay their respects to the victims, meet with first responders, and grieve with the community. The alleged gunman, Robert Card, was found dead of an apparent suicide after a manhunt. Investigators are focusing on Card's mental health as a possible motive.

entry.title: Republicans to join Dems in breaking Tuberville's blockade on military promotions: report
entry.summary: Sen. Tommy Tuberville's (R-AL) blockade appears to be coming to an end, according to an MSNBC report. Capitol reporter Ali Vitali said that a group of Republicans were going to take to the Senate floor and force a vote with Democrats to marginalize Tuberville's protest against military promotions that has led to a reduced military readiness for the United States, according to reports. After a discussion about the absurdity of the protest, host Nicolle Wallace said that she recalled the era when Republicans had to be supportive of the military or they'd be shamed by leaders like Sen. Mitch McConnell (R-KY) and the GOP speaker. POLL: Should Trump be allowed to run for office? Taking to social media, reporter Andrew Desiderio confirmed the reporting, saying that the floor actions will take place tonight, where they will ask for unanimous consent on ending the Tuberville blockade. He said that he was told it would be led by Sen. Dan Sullivan (R-AK). The news comes after reports that McConnell threatened Sen. Josh Hawley (R-MO) over his bill to stop corporations from being able to give money to campaigns. McConnell reportedly pointed to Hawley in the caucus lunch and said he wouldn't be there if it wasn't for the money from his Senate Leadership PAC. He went on to threaten any member who supported the bill with a primary. It's the first such action heard about from McConnell since he suffered serious injuries from a series of falls and then appeared to freeze at various public press availabilities.

POLL: Should Trump be allowed to run for office? entry.title: Donald Trump Jr testifies he never worked on the key documents in his father's civil fraud trial
entry.summary: Donald Trump Jr testified in a civil fraud trial that he never worked on his father's financial statements, which are at the center of the trial. The lawsuit alleges that the former president and his business misled banks and insurers by inflating his net worth on the statements. Trump Jr said he signed off on the statements as a trustee but left the work to outside accountants. Eric Trump is also expected to testify in the trial, followed by the former president himself. The trial is in its second month and is being closely watched.

entry.title: Uganda court fines US couple $28,000 for 'inhumane treatment' of their foster child
entry.summary: A US couple has been fined $28,000 by a court in Uganda after pleading guilty to child cruelty and "inhumane treatment" of their 10-year-old foster child. The couple admitted to making the child sleep on a wooden platform and feeding him cold food. They were sentenced to two months in prison, which they have already served, and ordered to pay the victim $26,000 in compensation. The case has sparked criticism from child rights activists in Uganda, who have called it a travesty of justice.

entry.title: For China's jobless young people, hostels are the place to be
entry.summary: Hostels in China have become refuges for young people struggling to find jobs in major cities. As joblessness among young Chinese reaches record highs, hostels provide a place for individuals to stay between interviews and strategize for their next networking meeting. The hypercompetitive nature of China's white-collar job market, combined with a slowing economy, has made it increasingly difficult for young people to secure well-paying jobs. Even those who have found employment often struggle to afford housing. The situation has worsened in recent years, with fewer job offers available.

The new charges filed against him Tuesday included manslaughter and assault as hate crimes. Augustin faces up to 25 years in prison if convicted.

entry.title: 29-year-old Indian student stabbed at gym in US, critical
entry.summary: A 29-year-old student from Telangana, India, named Putcha Varun Raj, was stabbed in the head by a man at a gym in Indiana, United States. The attacker, Jordan Andrade, claimed that he found Varun "a little weird" and felt threatened by him. Varun, who was pursuing his MS in computer science, had a slim chance of survival due to the severity of his injuries. Varun's family has requested assistance from the government, and the Indian embassy and NRIs from Telangana have pledged their support.

entry.title: New details emerge after Matthew Perry's autopsy, cause of death 'deferred'
entry.summary: Actor Matthew Perry was found unresponsive and not breathing in his hot tub at his California residence. The Los Angeles Fire Department arrived at the scene but Perry was already deceased. An autopsy has been completed, but the cause of death has been deferred pending further tests. Foul play is not suspected at this time. Perry was best known for his role as Chandler Bing on the sitcom "Friends," and his co-stars have expressed their grief over his loss.

entry.title: US commandos on the ground in Israel helping to locate hostages
entry.summary: American commandos are assisting Israel in locating and rescuing the hostages taken during Hamas' cross-border attacks. The US Special Operations forces are working alongside FBI and state department experts to coordinate efforts with Israeli counterparts. While the commandos are not assigned combat roles, they are advising on the complexities of a potential ground invasion of Gaza. The US forces in the region are also prepared to assist American citizens and secure embassies if needed. The exact number of commandos deployed has not been disclosed.

entry.summary: Jordan, a key US ally, said Wednesday it has recalled its ambassador from Israel and told Israel's ambassador to remain out of the country in protest over the "humanitarian catastrophe" in Gaza. Jordan's deputy PM said the return of the ambassadors is linked to Israel "stopping its war on Gaza ... and the humanitarian catastrophe it is causing." Jordan signed a peace deal with Israel in 1994. Meanwhile, Bolivia said on Tuesday it had broken diplomatic ties with Israel

entry.title: 28 countries and EU sign pact against AI's 'catastrophic' risks
entry.summary: Countries such as India, UK, US, and China have agreed to collaborate in order to protect against the potential harm caused by artificial intelligence (AI). This agreement was reached at the world's first summit on AI safety, held in Bletchley Park, UK. The participating nations signed the "Bletchley Declaration," emphasizing the need to collectively manage the risks associated with AI. While the declaration lacks specific policy goals, a second meeting is scheduled in South Korea and a third in France.

Images disseminated by the military showed Saar-class corvettes patrolling near Eilat port in the Red Sea, which Israel sees as a new front as its war in Gaza draws retaliation from Iran-aligned pro-Hamas forces elsewhere in the region

entry.title: First evacuees exit Gaza as refugee camp struck again
entry.summary: At least 320 foreign passport holders and injured Gazans were evacuated from the Palestinian enclave through the Rafah crossing into Egypt on Wednesday, under a deal mediated by Qatar. Initially, 500 foreign passport holders were expected to be allowed out of Gaza in the coming days. Talks are ongoing for further evacuations, with the US aiming to evacuate 400 Americans. The limited evacuations come after more than three weeks of a total blockade of Gaza by Israel, following an attack by Hamas fighters. Hospitals in Gaza are also facing a critical shortage of fuel.

entry.title: US Federal Reserve keeps interest rates at 22-year high
entry.summary: The US Federal Reserve has decided to maintain interest rates at a 22-year high for the second consecutive meeting in an effort to control inflation without harming the strong economy. The Fed aims to cool down demand and encourage companies to slow down price increases. Despite the economy's resilience, inflation has gradually decreased from its peak in 2022. The Fed is focused on bringing inflation back in line with its 2% target and is considering whether to implement one final rate increase in the coming months.

entry.title: There Are Currently 40,000 U.S. Ground Troops In The Middle East
entry.summary:
Axios: Where U.S. troops are stationed in the Middle East
With the Israel-Hamas war escalating, the United States risks becoming involved in a larger conflict that could entangle some of the more than 40,000 U.S. military personnel based across the region.
Why it matters: U.S. troops and military contractors in Iraq and Syria have been targeted in over a dozen attacks by Iranian-backed militia groups since Hamas' surprise attack against Israeli civilians and soldiers on Oct. 7. * Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin has warned of the "prospect of a significant escalation of attacks on our troops and our people throughout the region." * Between the lines: The attacks, as well as a wider war, could reverse efforts in recent years to reduce the U.S. presence in the Middle East as part of a strategic pivot to toward the Pacific.
Read more ....

entry.title: Italy PM Giorgia Meloni talks of Ukraine fatigue, migration in prank call
entry.summary: Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni expressed international fatigue with the conflict in Ukraine and a lack of support for Italy in dealing with migration in a phone call with Russian pranksters. The 13-minute audio of the call, released by the pranksters, revealed Meloni's frustration with the situation. She also criticized the belief that Italy should solve the migration problem alone. The pranksters praised Meloni for sharing her genuine opinions, unlike other European politicians who act like programmed robots.

entry.title: Germany Blocks Sale Of Typhoon Jets To Saudi Arabia
entry.summary:
Saudi Arabia Eurofighter Typhoon – Wikipedia
EruAsian Times: French Rafales ‘Trounce’ Eurofighters As Germany Blocks Sale Of Typhoon Jets To Saudi Arabia – Reports
Germany loosened export restrictions against Saudi Arabia earlier this year. Still, it refused to allow the sale of the 4.5th generation Eurofighter Typhoon fighter jet to the kingdom, despite the UK government’s intense lobbying. Berlin’s refusal, unfortunately, poses a significant challenge to Britain’s production lines. The United Kingdom is likely to see a loss of 6,000 jobs in the defense sector and no manufacturing of fighter jets for a decade in the face of Germany’s unwillingness to green-light the sale of Eurofighter Typhoon jets to the Royal Saudi Air Force, British newspaper The Sun reported. Berlin is blocking a multibillion-dollar agreement to sell 48 Typhoons to Saudi Arabia, and ministers have threatened to “close” BAE production lines if the contract is refused. German Chancellor Olaf Scholz clarified in July this year that Germany will not deliver Eurofighter combat aircraft to Saudi Arabia soon.
Read more ....
WNU Editor: The impact on the UK for losing this sale is going to be huge .... More than 6,000 UK jobs are put at risk as Germany controversially BLOCKS a deal to sell British-made Typhoon fighter jets to Saudi Arabia (Daily Mail).

entry.title: No, this video doesn’t show a Palestinian pretending to be injured in the Israel-Hamas war
entry.summary: Some pro-Israeli social media users are claiming that Palestinians are posting videos pretending to be injured by the bombing campaign carried out by Israel since October 7. On October 26, for example, pro-Israeli accounts started sharing claims that a Palestinian video maker had pretended to be injured. Their so-called proof was two videos – one said to show the man in a hospital bed and the next one, apparently filmed the next day, showing him in perfect health. It turns out, however, that the video of the injured man is from August 2023, months before the war broke out. Moreover, it shows another man – and a real victim of the ongoing conflict.

entry.summary:
Columbia-class submarine construction remains a Pentagon priority. (US Navy)
James: Struggles continue for US Navy to meet submarine-building requirements, commitments The US Navy (USN) has continued to face difficulties in delivering Virginia-class attack submarines (SSNs), maintaining existing vessels, and gearing up for the construction and delivery schedule for the Columbia-class ballistic missile submarines (SSBNs) meant to replace the Ohio-class boats for the US fleets. Meeting the requirements for the trinational Australian, UK, and US (AUKUS) agreement to bolster the Australian submarine fleet will likely mean a dip in the US submarine fleet below its future goals and needs, according to a recent report by the Congressional Budget Office (CBO). entry.title: North Korea Closes A Dozen Embassies Around The World
entry.summary:
Reuters: North Korea closes multiple embassies around the world
North Korea is poised to close as many as a dozen embassies including in Spain, Hong Kong, and multiple countries in Africa, according to media reports and analysts, in a move that could see nearly 25 percent of Pyongyang's missions close worldwide. North Korea's recent closing of its diplomatic missions was a sign that the reclusive country is struggling to make money overseas because of international sanctions, South Korea's unification ministry said on Tuesday. On Monday, North Korean state media outlet KCNA said the country's ambassadors paid "farewell" visits to Angolan and Ugandan leaders last week, and local media in both African countries reported the shutdown of the North's embassies there.
Read more ....
WNU Editor: Running an embassy or any other diplomatic office is not cheap. And with the West enforcing sanctions, it makes no economic sense to have one in a place like Angola or Uganda. North Korea Closes A Dozen Embassies Around The World North Korea shuts down multiple embassies, South Korea speculates financial issues are the reason -- FOX News
North Korea closes several overseas embassies amid sanctions woes -- UPI

entry.summary: Chinese brewer Tsingtao says a worker who was filmed urinating into a malt container has been detained by security authorities.

entry.title: Stricken ferry that was leaking oil into sea pulled free - as new oil spill found
entry.summary: A ferry that ran aground and leaked oil into the Baltic Sea has been pulled free - with the rescue operation revealing another oil spill, the Swedish coastguard has said.

entry.title: Up First briefing: Gaza-Egypt Rafah crossing partially opens; Trump family testifies
entry.summary: The Rafah crossing between Gaza and Egypt is open for some foreign passport holders and dozens of injured people to evacuate. Donald Trump Jr. and his family are set to testify in a civil fraut trial.

entry.title: Chad's military government agrees to opposition leader's return from exile
entry.summary: Chad's military government has agreed to allow the return of opposition leader Succes Masra, who fled the country last year amid a political clampdown, the Congolese presidency announced Tuesday.

entry.title: Foreign passport holders enter Rafah crossing from Gaza to Egypt
entry.summary: Dozens of people entered the Rafah crossing from Gaza to Egypt on Wednesday. It appeared to be the first time foreign passport holders have been allowed to leave the besieged territory since the start of the Israel-Hamas war more than three weeks ago.

entry.title: 'Origin story' of Great Sphinx of Giza discovered
entry.summary: With the face of a woman and the body of a lion, the Great Sphinx of Giza has enthralled and mystified archaeologists for thousands of years.

entry.title: German court issues penalty order against Zverev over allegation he caused bodily harm to a woman
entry.summary: A German court has issued a penalty order against tennis player Alexander Zverev over allegations he caused bodily harm to a woman. Zverev has disputed the allegations and is contesting the penalty order.

entry.title: South Korea's spy agency says North Korea shipped more than a million artillery shells to Russia
entry.summary: South Korea's top spy agency believes North Korea sent more than a million artillery shells to Russia since August to help fuel Russian President Vladimir Putin's war on Ukraine, according to a lawmaker who attended a closed-door briefing Wednesday with intelligence officials.

entry.title: Liverpool star Luis Diaz breaks silence on parents' kidnapping
entry.summary: Liverpool footballer Luis Diaz has called for the release of his father, urging kidnappers to "free him now".

entry.title: Stars of David spray-painted on Paris buildings 'recall events of the 1930s'
entry.summary: Stars of David have been daubed on buildings in Paris in a display of antisemitism that recalls the dark times of the 1930s, authorities say.

entry.title: King Charles III visits war cemetery in Kenya after voicing 'deepest regret' for colonial violence
entry.summary: King Charles III visited a war cemetery in Nairobi on Wednesday, laying a wreath in honor of Kenyans who fought alongside the British in the two world wars, a day after the monarch expressed "greatest sorrow and the deepest regret" for the violence of the colonial era.

entry.title: Researchers hope tracking senior Myanmar army officers can ascertain blame for human rights abuses
entry.summary: A group of human rights researchers officially launched a website Wednesday that they hope will help get justice for victims of state violence in Myanmar, where one of the world's less-noticed but still brutal armed struggles is taking place.

entry.title: First Americans and other foreign nationals leave besieged Gaza
entry.summary: It's the first time people have been allowed to exit the Palestinian territory since the Oct. 7 Hamas attacks on Israel. Ambulances took dozens of seriously wounded people to hospitals in Egypt.

entry.title: U.K. summit aims to tackle thorny issues around cutting-edge AI risks
entry.summary: Digital officials, tech company bosses and researchers are converging Wednesday at a former codebreaking spy base near London to discuss and better understand the extreme risks posed by cutting-edge artificial intelligence.

entry.title: Bangladesh launches new India-assisted rail projects and thermal power unit amid opposition protests
entry.summary: India and Bangladesh launched two new railway links and a thermal power plant unit Wednesday to strengthen connections and energy security in the region amid strong opposition protests in Bangladesh.

entry.summary: The first British nationals have left Gaza and crossed the Rafah border into Egypt, the Foreign Office has said.

entry.title: Governors show solidarity with Israel, earning plaudits and criticism
entry.summary: Eleven days after Hamas terrorists poured into southern Israel from the Gaza Strip, killing at least 1,400 people and kidnapping more than 230, New York Gov. Kathy Hochul arrived in Israel with a photo of a Long Island native in hand to give to the president of the besieged country. Hochul, the Democratic governor of a state that has the largest Jewish population in the world outside of Israel, told the media in the aftermath of the Oct. 7 attack that she wanted to “bear witness” to the tragedy, show New York’s “unwavering” support of Israel and make sure that missing New Yorkers such as Omer ...

entry.title: Dozens of Afghans who were illegally in Pakistan are detained and deported in nationwide sweeps
entry.summary: Pakistani security forces on Wednesday detained and deported dozens of Afghans who were living in the country illegally, after a government-set deadline for them to leave expired, authorities said.

entry.title: China keeps up military pressure on Taiwan, sending 43 planes and 7 ships near self-governing island
entry.summary: Taiwan said Wednesday that China sent 43 military aircraft and seven ships near the self-ruled island, the latest sign that Beijing plans no let-up in its campaign of harassment, threats and intimidation.

entry.title: 'Neener-neenerism': Analyst shreds GOP's 'stupid and gross' conditions to fund Israel
entry.summary: House Republicans, lead by newly minted Speaker Mike Johnson (R-LA), are demanding that the cost of the aid package to Israel be "offset" by $14 billion in cuts to IRS enforcement funding guaranteed in President Joe Biden's Inflation Reduction Act — which is not only unrelated to the issue at hand, but experts say it would actually increase the deficit. The fact that Republicans are demanding an increase in tax evasion as their condition of supporting a key U.S. ally's military is not an accident, argued Talking Points Memo's Josh Marshall on MSNBC Tuesday, but a sign of how low the GOP has sunk. "I have to say, Josh, like, Mike Johnson rolling out, going after the IRS on a must-pass is past even a caricature, I can imagine, of a priority from the Republican House speaker," said anchor Chr…

entry.title: 'Desperate threat': Top Dems say Tuberville could be behind Marine leader's health scare
entry.summary: After Marine Corps Gen. Eric Smith suffered landed in the hospital Sunday following "an apparent heart attack," Senate Armed Services Chair Jack Reed (D-Rhode Island) alleged U.S. Senator Tommy Tuberville's (R-Alabama) military promotions hold may have contributed, Politico reports. Politico notes the Alabama senator "has maintained the blockade over the Pentagon's abortion travel policy, ensnaring more than 300 generals and admirals at the upper rungs of the armed forces." Reed told the news outlet, "One of the reasons, I think contributed to his condition was he was doing two jobs at once. I've read where he was working from 5 a.m. to 11 p.m. As a result, if he had, as is normal, an assistant, he could switch off." POLL: Should Trump be allowed to hold office again? Per the report, he ad…

entry.title: Ukraine's Zelensky says fight for Black Sea will go down in history
entry.summary: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky on Tuesday said Kiev's forces will succeed in their fighting in future, particularly in the Black Sea region, even if the situation on the front is difficult at present. "The modern world is designed to get used to success too quickly. When the aggression started in full swing, many people in the world expected that Ukraine would not hold out," Zelensky said in his daily address late on Tuesday. "Meanwhile, the colossal achievements of our people, of all our soldiers, are simply taken for granted." "Ukraine's success in the battle for the Black Sea will g...

entry.title: Spain's Princess Leonor swears allegiance to divided nation on her 18th birthday
entry.summary: By David Latona MADRID (Reuters) - Princess Leonor, the heir to Spain's throne, formally stepped into the spotlight by swearing allegiance to the constitution on her 18th birthday on Tuesday, though boycotts by leftist and separatist politicians underlined divisions over the monarchy. The ceremony in parliament marked her coming of age, meaning she will now directly become queen after her father King Felipe VI, assuming he does not go on to have any male children. The princess, who went to school in Wales and started three years of military training in Spain in August, vowed to uphold the law,...

entry.title: UN human rights official resigns over ‘textbook case of genocide’ in Gaza
entry.summary: NEW YORK — A New York-based United Nations human rights official has resigned over the organization’s response to the situation in Gaza, which he described as a “textbook case of genocide.” Craig Mokhiber, the director in the New York Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights, announced his resignation in a letter shared publicly on Tuesday — more than three weeks into the Israel-Hamas conflict. “This is a textbook case of genocide,” he wrote in an Oct. 28 letter to Volker Türk, the UN’s High Commissioner for Human Rights. “The European, ethno-nationalist, settler colonial project in Pa...

entry.title: A world record in race walking is erased after the course was measured wrong
entry.summary: Peru's Kimberly García thought she had smashed a world record by more than 10 minutes. It turns out the course was almost two miles too short.

entry.title: Gaza's 34-hour phone and internet blackout, as told in voice memos
entry.summary: Voice memos recorded by NPR's producer in Gaza during a 34-hour communications blackout convey a weekend of anxiety and uncertainty for Palestinians as Israeli ground troops invaded.

entry.title: Dominican Republic allows some Haiti flights as OAS arrives to meet about border dispute
entry.summary: After banning all air travel with neighboring Haiti in adiplomatic row over the construction of a canal on Haitian soil, authorities in the Dominican Republic have relaxed their stance. But Dominican Republic President Luis Abinader says a decision announced on Monday by his Civil Aviation Board to lift a Sept. 15 ban on flights between the two countries, which share the island of Hispaniola, only applies to some individuals in Haiti, principally Haitian diplomats and Haitian nationals with Dominican visas who already had flight reservations. “It is a fairly small group,” he said about as he s...

entry.title: US says Putin seeking to 'take advantage' of Israel-Hamas war
entry.summary: Washington (AFP) - The United States accused Russian President Vladimir Putin Tuesday of trying to use the Israel-Hamas war to reduce Western support for Ukraine, which it said requires continued backing from Washington to prevent Russia success. Hamas militants carried out a shock cross-border attack from Gaza this month that Israeli officials say killed more than 1,400 people, prompting Washington to rush military aid to Israel and sparking fears in Kyiv that backing for its war against invading Russian forces could suffer. "Putin is very much trying to take advantage of the Hamas attack on ...

entry.title: El Salvador imposed a new $1000 fee for passengers with an African passport. Here’s why
entry.summary: The government of El Salvador is charging a new $1,000 fee for passengers from African countries that fly into its capital’s international airport, a measure that comes as countries in the Western Hemisphere aim to stem a record flow of migration across the region. Salvadorean port authorities said that the measure would be applied to passengers in transit earlier this month, and that the tariffs were for “airport improvements” as more passengers were entering, leaving, and connecting through San Salvador this year compared to previous ones. “The Government of President Nayib Bukele is working...

entry.title: Israel military says it hit a Hamas leader responsible for October 7
entry.summary: The Israeli military on Tuesday said that its fighter jets struck a senior Hamas commander who was responsible for the October 7 terrorist attacks on two communities. Nasim Abu Ajina "directed the massacre on October 7th in the Kibbutz Erez and Moshav Netiv HaAsara," the Israel Defense Forces (IDF) and the Israeli Security Agency (ISA) said in a joint statement posted on Telegram. "In the past, Abu Ajina commanded Hamas' Aerial Array, and took part in the development of the UAVs and paragliders of the terrorist organization," the statement continued. "His elimination significantly harms the ef...

entry.title: How Nicaragua is helping – and charging – Haitians who want to reach the United States
entry.summary: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti – Across the street from the departure terminal at Toussaint Louverture International Airport in Haiti’s gang-plagued capital, hundreds of anxious travelers spill out onto the road from an overflowing parking lot, listening for their Nicaragua-bound flight to be called. As ticket agents in white shirts walk through the chaotic crowd, there is chatter about how many days some have been camping out and the desperation driving them to Managua, the new migration springboard for migrants seeking asylum in the United States. “There is nowhere that is simple,” one young man says...

entry.title: Britain's King Charles begins Kenya visit steeped in 'painful' colonial history
entry.summary: By Duncan Miriri NAIROBI (Reuters) - Britain's King Charles begins a four-day state visit to Kenya on Tuesday, his first to a former colony, during which he plans to acknowledge "painful aspects" of a shared history that included almost seven decades of colonial rule. Accompanied by Queen Camilla, Charles arrived in the East African country overnight and will be received by Kenyan President William Ruto in the capital Nairobi on Tuesday morning. Buckingham Palace says the visit is a reflection of the two countries' close cooperation on economic development, climate change and security issues. ...

entry.title: Venezuela's top court suspends results of opposition presidential primary
entry.summary: By Mayela Armas and Vivian Sequera CARACAS (Reuters) - Venezuela's Supreme Justice Tribunal said on Monday it has suspended the results of an opposition presidential primary that took place this month, despite an electoral deal between the government and the opposition that allows each side to choose its candidate. The ruling could risk the wrath of the United States, which this month rolled back some oil and gas industry and bond trading sanctions in exchange for the electoral deal. The U.S. State Department has already said it will reinstate sanctions if the government of President Nicolas M...

entry.title: Kenyans urge King Charles III to formally apologize for colonial-era abuses
entry.summary: King Charles III didn’t receive the warmest of welcomes when he arrived in Kenya for a four-day state visit on Monday. Calls are growing for the British monarch to make a heartfelt apology for colonial era abuses as he and Queen Camilla tour the east African country. The tour is the first to a Commonwealth country since he succeeded his late mother, Queen Elizabeth, who died in September after a seven-decade reign. Buckingham Palace announced that King Charles would “acknowledge the more painful aspects of the U.K. and Kenya’s shared history,” which includes the bloody Mau Mau rebellion of the...

entry.title: Hamas says it fires on Israeli troops pressing Gaza ground assault
entry.summary: By Nidal al-Mughrabi and Emily Rose GAZA/JERUSALEM (Reuters) - Hamas said its militants fired machine guns and anti-tank missiles toward Israeli forces in north and south Gaza early on Tuesday as Israel's tanks and infantry attacked the enclave's main city, raising concerns about the plight of Palestinian civilians. Israel has expanded ground operations in Gaza as it seeks to punish Hamas for a deadly gun rampage three weeks ago that Israeli authorities say killed over 1,400 people. Witnesses said Israeli forces targeted Gaza's main north-south road on Monday and attacked Gaza City from two di...

entry.title: UK prepares to host global leaders' gathering on AI
entry.summary: London (AFP) - The UK government will welcome foreign political leaders, tech industry figures, academics and others this week for a two-day summit billed as the first of its kind on artificial intelligence (AI). The gathering, set to be attended by Prime Minister Rishi Sunak, US Vice President Kamala Harris, EU chief Ursula von der Leyen and UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres, will focus on growing fears about the implications of so-called frontier AI. The most advanced generation of AI models, they have prompted concerns around everything from job losses and cyber attacks to humans losin...

entry.title: Far-right AfD politician arrested in Germany
entry.summary: A 22-year-old Bavarian politician from the far-right Alternative for Germany (AfD) party was arrested on Monday in connection with incitement and the use of symbols illegal under German law. Daniel Halemba, who recently became the youngest politician to be elected to the Bavarian state parliament, was apprehended after a warrant was issued for his arrest five days ago, a spokesman for the Würzburg public prosecutor's office told dpa on Monday. Polish-born Halemba is being investigated for incitement and the use of symbols of anti-constitutional organizations. He was taken into custody in the S...

entry.title: Israeli military rescues soldier kidnapped by Hamas during nighttime operation
entry.summary: The Israel Defense Forces, during a nighttime ground operation, successfully liberated a soldier who was kidnapped by Hamas, according to the statement by the IDF. "Overnight, the soldier PVT Ori Megidish was released during ground operations. PVT Megidish was kidnapped by the Hamas terrorist organization on October 7th," the statement reads. It is mentioned that the soldier has undergone a medical examination and is feeling well. She has already been reunited with her family. Expansion of Israel's ground operation On October 7th, Hamas terrorists unexpectedly attacked Israel. The militants ki...

entry.title: Zelensky holiday home on Crimea auctioned off by Russian occupiers
entry.summary: The Crimean home owned by Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky's family has been auctioned off by the occupying Russian authorities, the Russian state news agency TASS reported on Monday. The 120-square metre apartment in the luxury resort of Yalta on the south of the peninsula went for 44.3 million roubles ($480,000), almost twice the starting bid. There were only two bidders. The official previous owner was Zelensky's wife Olena, who bought it in 2013, a year before Russia seized the peninsula. At the time, Zelensky was still working as an actor. The apartment has three rooms with a view o...

entry.title: Hamas hostage Shani Louk, abducted during Israeli music festival, reported dead
entry.summary: Israeli festival-goer Shani Louk, who was abducted by Hamas terrorists on Oct. 7, is dead, according Israel’s Foreign Ministry. The 23-year-old German-Israeli woman was widely seen lying limp in the back of a truck after militants raided the Nova music festival near the Gaza Strip. She was recognized by tattoos on her legs. “We are devastated to share that the death of 23 year old German-Israeli Shani Luk was confirmed.” Israeli officials posted on social media Monday morning. “Shani who was kidnapped from a music festival and tortured and paraded around Gaza by Hamas terrorists, experienced u...

entry.title: Mitch McConnell on 'collision course' with new GOP speaker: report
entry.summary: Newly appointed House Speaker Mike Johnson (R-LA) has a record of opposing military assistance to Ukraine. Since taking charge of the House, he has not outright said he will block Ukraine aid — but he has made clear it will not be coupled to his planned aid package to Israel, claiming the latter is more urgent of a need. But if Johnson continues to obstruct Ukraine aid, he is headed for a "collision course" with his counterpart in Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-KY), who is committed to continuing to defend Eastern Europe against Russian aggression, reported Politico on Monday. According to Burgess Everett, McConnell's outspoken lobbying efforts to sway Republican senators to passing Ukraine relief "is a sharp deviation from his usual more reserved, consensus-building approach" a…

entry.title: Spanish musician María José Llergo turns roots into wings with ‘Ultrabelleza’
entry.summary: ​​​​​​​The Spanish artist María José Llergo has just released her first full-length album, called “Ultrabelleza.” Her voice carries the legacy of flamenco, the traditional music of her homeland, but on this new record, her roots have turned into wings, allowing her to explore other genres.

entry.title: Copper mine protests roil in Panama
entry.summary: The government approved a new contract with the mine late last week. Since then, protests have rippled across Panama, and people are afraid they could bring the country to a standstill.

entry.title: Zimbabwe's stone sculptors struggle to keep carving
entry.summary: International art collectors purchased many of Zimbabwe's massive stone carvings. But buyers stopped coming in 2000 after conflict over land reform policies led to violence. Some sculptors are still trying to keep their art alive.

entry.title: How this Cambodian American singer found her voice

entry.summary: RAND researchers are available to comment on Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelenskyy's remarks this week to the U.N. General Assembly in New York City and to U.S. policymakers, including President Biden and members of the 118th Congress, in Washington, D.C.

entry.title: UBC anthropologist reflects on Oppenheimer and 78th anniversary of nuclear bombing of Nagasaki
entry.summary: Hugh Gusterson, an anthropologist with expertise in militarism and nuclear policy at the University of British Columbia, encourages viewers of Oppenheimer to think about the grave threat that nuclear weapons pose to humanity.

entry.title: Heavy rains cause partial dam collapse, flooding in Norway
entry.summary: Storm Hans battered Norway with heavy rains Tuesday and Wednesday. Flooding of the Braskereidfoss power dam control room prevented the hatches from opening, causing a partial collapse and flooding downriver. The heavy rains provoked mudslides and swollen rivers which swept away some structures and flooded towns, requiring the evacuation of more than 3,000 people and isolating others.

entry.title: Tropical storm Khanun blowing into South Korea after battering Japan for a week
entry.summary: Rains and winds are growing in southern South Korea due to a tropical storm that's expected to slam into major urban areas.

entry.title: 6 killed in Hawaii wildfires, Maui mayor says
entry.summary: Wildfires fanned by the winds of a distant hurricane devastated Hawaii's Maui island on Wednesday, killing at least six people, Maui County Mayor Richard Bissen said at a news conference.

entry.title: 11 killed in France after fire at vacation home for adults with learning disabilities
entry.summary: A fire ripped through a vacation home for adults with disabilities in eastern France on Wednesday, killing 11 people, officials said.

entry.title: Beijing's flooding death toll rises to 33, with 18 still missing
entry.summary: The death toll from recent flooding in China's capital rose to 33, including five rescuers, and another 18 people are missing, officials said Wednesday. Much of the country's north remains threatened by unusually heavy rainfall.

entry.title: Who is responsible for Turkey’s bad buildings?
entry.summary:
Buildings destroyed after the earthquake on February 13, 2023, in Hatay, Turkey. | Murat Saka/dia images via Getty Images
Turkey is investigating and has arrested some contractors, but the entire political and economic system is implicated. Turkey is still in the middle of an emergency, reeling from the earthquake that killed at least 35,000 people last week. But the finger-pointing has already begun. The rush to punishment comes amid the grief, but also the mounting fury and frustration over the Turkish government’s earthquake response. Much of that is focused on the emergency response — waiting for aid and rescue teams — but it is also extending to anger about policies before the earthquake, about how shoddy building construction may have exacerbated the devastation of the dis…

entry.title: 10 years ago, we were turning nuclear bombs into nuclear energy. We can do it again.
entry.summary:
Getty Images
How we turned 20,000 Soviet nukes into zero-carbon energy — and how we can do the same with some of our own. Just a decade ago, one in 10 American lightbulbs was powered by dismantled Russian nuclear weapons. That was made possible by the Megatons to Megawatts program, an agreement negotiated after the collapse of the Soviet Union to convert uranium from Russia’s nuclear weapons stockpile into fuel for US nuclear power plants. The unconventional policy was first proposed by MIT physicist Thomas Neff in a 1991 New York Times op-ed. By the time Megatons to Megawatts ran its full course from 1993 to 2013, it had eliminated about 20,000 nuclear warheads and stood out as a point of shared pride in the often jaded arms control and disarmament field. “Nearly every commercia…

entry.title: Why earthquakes are deadlier depending on where you live
entry.summary:
Volunteers stand on rubble of a destroyed building in Kahramanmaras, Turkey, on February 7, 2023. | Adem Altan/AFP via Getty Images
What Turkey and Syria’s deadly earthquakes reveal about wealth. In the early hours of Monday, February 6, residents living in southern Turkey and northern Syria were woken by violent shaking, collapsing buildings, and sweeping blackouts. The earthquake buried residents in rubble and was followed by powerful aftershocks. By the following Monday, the death toll had passed 36,000 people. “It was like the apocalypse,” Abdul Salam al-Mahmoud, a resident of Atareb, Syria, told Reuters. The country is no stranger to quakes, having lost 17,000 people to a 7.4-magnitude tremor in 1999. But while last week’s earthquake was a 7.8-magnitude quake, and had an u…

entry.title: Why the balloon and UFO affairs are a Sputnik moment
entry.summary:
A suspected Chinese spy balloon flies above Charlotte, North Carolina, on February 4, 2023. | Peter Zay/Anadolu Agency via Getty Images
As all these objects fall, a new space race is rising. Now that the US military has shot down a suspected spy balloon from China and three other unidentified flying objects, there will be debates about the UFOs’ meaning, their capabilities, and why they were all up there in the first place. Though former CIA Director Michael Hayden said the initial balloon’s threat to the welfare of Americans was vastly inflated, others described the incident as a wake-up call. Former Trump national security adviser H.R. McMaster hopes it will lead to a “Sputnik moment,” harkening back to the US space race with the Soviet Union. The Wall Street Journal even war…

entry.title: Why retailers are bullish on New York's luxury hallways
entry.summary: Midtown is booming, brokers say, thanks to the return of office workers and tourists. “We are totally back,” said Steven Soutendijk, executive managing director at Cushman & Wakefield. Retailers around Midtown office corridors “live and die with office density, and we’re seeing a noticeable difference,” said David LaPierre, vice president of CBRE. Now, there doesn’t seem to be a shortage of old and new concepts. “It’s like the city and retailers have woken up,” said Jared Epstein, president and chief executive of Aurora Capital Associates. “We had stock on just about everything from Soho to the Meatpacking District, West Village, Midtown and Brooklyn. There’s clothing, food, fitness, healthcare, and interest at every level, with spaces filling up fast. At Madison Avenue on the Upper …
